title: Motivation & Recognition
description: Diagnose motivation issues using Herzberg and Maslow theories—money doesn't fix everything.
objectives: Diagnose intrinsic (challenge, growth) vs extrinsic (salary, recognition) motivation issues
Apply Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory to distinguish hygiene factors from motivators
Use Maslow's Hierarchy to identify which need level is blocking motivation
Recognize Theory X vs Theory Y management assumptions
Design recognition strategies that are timely and culturally appropriate

screens.headline: 3 Demotivated Team Members. 3 Different Causes. Money Won't Fix Them All.

dialogue.text: Just give everyone a bonus. Money solves motivation problems.

counterpoint.text: If you don't diagnose the root cause, you'll waste money AND lose people.

screens.learningHook: Three demotivated team members. Three different causes. Diagnose before you prescribe.

screens.title: Motivation Diagnostic
screens.instructions: For each team member: diagnose the issue type and select the best intervention.

scenarios.title: Elena (Sous Chef) - Missing Recognition
description: Expected performance bonus after project success (verbally mentioned by previous manager)
Didn't receive it—HR says 'bonuses are discretionary'
Now withdrawn, no longer volunteers, productivity dropped

quote.text: I gave everything to that project. Worked weekends, mentored juniors, exceeded every target. And nothing. I just want to be acknowledged.

questions.question: Is Elena's issue INTRINSIC (challenge/autonomy) or EXTRINSIC (recognition/reward)?
What intervention addresses Elena's root cause?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Elena needs RECOGNITION (extrinsic). Public acknowledgment + ongoing recognition addresses her esteem need without requiring a bonus.
feedback.incorrect: Elena said 'I just want to be acknowledged.' She needs recognition, not challenge (intrinsic) or just money.

scenarios.title: Marco (Head Chef) - Bored Expert
description: Recently assigned routine prep work due to staffing shortages
Vocally complaining: 'A junior cook could do this. Why am I here?'

quote.text: I didn't train for 15 years to chop onions. This is beneath my skill level. I need complex challenges—I'm losing my edge.

questions.question: Is Marco's issue INTRINSIC or EXTRINSIC?

options.text: Increase salary to compensate for boring work
Assign complex R&D project (fusion menu) with autonomy

feedback.correct: Excellent! Marco's issue is INTRINSIC—he needs challenge, not money. Assigning R&D with autonomy provides exactly what intrinsically motivates experts.
feedback.incorrect: Marco said he needs complex challenges—money doesn't fix boredom. He's at Maslow's self-actualization level; he needs growth and mastery.

scenarios.title: Jamie (Operations Manager) - Safety & Burnout
description: Working 70-hour weeks to manually monitor temperatures

quote.text: I don't want a bonus. I want safe working conditions and reasonable hours. The fridge is broken and I'm overworked.

questions.question: According to Herzberg, is Jamie's issue a HYGIENE factor or MOTIVATOR?
What intervention addresses Jamie's root cause?

options.text: Offer performance bonus for handling crisis
Fix refrigeration system + reduce hours to 40/week
Assign stretch goal (design new ops system)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Jamie's issue is HYGIENE (Herzberg): unsafe conditions + overwork. Fix safety FIRST—you can't motivate someone whose basic needs are unmet.
feedback.incorrect: Jamie explicitly said 'I don't want a bonus—I want safe conditions.' Offering money without fixing safety is insulting. Fix the hygiene factor first.

content.criticalRule: Money (extrinsic) doesn't fix intrinsic problems. A bored expert needs CHALLENGE, not a raise.

hygieneFactors.definition: Prevent dissatisfaction but don't CREATE motivation
hygieneFactors.rule: If missing → people are DISSATISFIED. Providing them just removes dissatisfaction.

motivators.rule: These actually MOTIVATE—but only after hygiene factors are met.

content.criticalDistinction: If someone lacks a HYGIENE factor (unsafe conditions), giving them a MOTIVATOR (praise) is insulting. Fix hygiene FIRST.

content.rule: Lower needs MUST be satisfied before higher needs motivate. Can't motivate with Esteem (L4) if Safety (L2) is unmet.
content.example: Jamie's Safety need (L2) is unmet. Recognition (L4) won't work until safety is restored.

theoryX.assumptions: People dislike work, avoid responsibility, need supervision
theoryX.risk: Becomes self-fulfilling—team disengages because not trusted

theoryY.assumptions: People are self-motivated, enjoy work, seek responsibility

content.insight: Theory X creates demotivation. Theory Y unlocks intrinsic motivation.

correct.text: Thank you for acknowledging my work. That's all I needed—to feel valued and seen.

incorrect.text: The new project is interesting, but that doesn't fix my frustration about the last project. I wanted acknowledgment.

correct.text: FINALLY. This is why I became a chef—to create and innovate, not to do routine prep.

incorrect.text: More money doesn't change the fact that I'm bored and underutilized. I don't need a raise—I need interesting work.

correct.text: THANK YOU for listening. I can finally do my job safely and get proper rest. That's all I needed.

incorrect.text: You think money fixes a broken fridge and 70-hour weeks? That's insulting. I'm quitting.

screens.title: Convince Carlos Money Isn't Universal
screens.context: Carlos proposes: 'Just give everyone a 15% raise. ALL three problems solved!'

scenario.title: Why Money Doesn't Work
scenario.challenge: Explain why a blanket raise won't fix Elena, Marco, or Jamie.

questions.question: Match each team member's problem type:

feedback.correct: Perfect! Three different root causes—money fixes none of them.
feedback.incorrect: Review each person's quotes. Elena needs recognition, Marco needs challenge, Jamie needs safety.

questions.question: Complete: 'Carlos, money won't work because Elena needs _____ (Herzberg _____), Marco is at _____ level, and Jamie's _____ must be fixed first.'

feedback.correct: Excellent! You correctly applied Herzberg and Maslow to explain why money doesn't work.
feedback.incorrect: Review the theories: Elena = recognition (Herzberg motivator), Marco = self-actualization (Maslow), Jamie = safety (Herzberg hygiene).

screens.title: Motivation Mastery
screens.summary: Diagnose before prescribing. Money doesn't fix intrinsic or hygiene problems—understand the root cause first.
takeaways: Intrinsic motivation (challenge, autonomy) is sustainable; extrinsic (money) is short-term
Herzberg: Fix HYGIENE factors (safety, fair pay) BEFORE offering motivators (recognition)
Maslow: Lower needs must be met before higher needs motivate
Recognition must be timely (throughout project), not just at the end
Theory X creates demotivation; Theory Y unlocks engagement

characterClosing.text: I thought money solved everything. You showed me Elena needed visibility, Marco needed challenge, and Jamie needed safety. Three different root causes. I was wrong.
